speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: Welcome to Open Minds from Creative Commons. I'm Eric Stoyer.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: As you may know, it's Creative Commons' 20th anniversary this year, and one of the ways we're celebrating is with this podcast,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: a series of conversations with people working on the issues we're involved with and subjects we're excited about.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: On today's episode, Sarah Pearson, Creative Commons Senior Counsel, speaks with Coraline Ada Emke.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: Emke has been an active contributor to the open source community for more than 25 years.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: She's a developer, writer, speaker, musician, and activist. She's the creator of

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: Contributor Covenant, which is a code of conduct used by more than 100,000 open-source projects

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: and communities. On Emke's website, she describes herself as being a big-time open-source troublemaker.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: She's opposed to the idea that open-source software

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: should be available to be used by anyone for any purpose.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: Her view stands in contrast to what is known as the open-source definition,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: which says that open-source licenses cannot limit who may use a program,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: even if they're evil.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: Emke is the creator of the Hippocratic License,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: which prohibits the use of open- source in conjunction with human rights violations.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: She's also behind the Organization for Ethical Source, an initiative that aims to ensure that the work of open source developers is being used for social good.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_02
speakers.text: I hope you enjoyed this conversation with Coraline Ada Emke.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: Well, I thought maybe we'd start the conversation by talking a little bit about your personal entry into open source specifically.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: So I've heard a little bit about how you got into software development, but I'm

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: curious about how you got specifically into open software and what drew you to it.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Sure. Well, I've been working with computers my entire life. And actually in the early days,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: when we got our first home computer, it was a TRS-80 and later a Commodore 64.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: There was no mechanism for software distribution aside from ordering floppies through the mail.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: Even, actually, to be clear, when I started, there weren't even floppies.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: You had cassette decks.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: So the standard way of getting programs on your computer when I started out was flipping through computer magazines

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: and literally typing in source code. So that open sharing of source code is how I learned.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: And of course, when that's your operating environment, you also want to give back.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: That's a natural human instinct. And so I did that throughout my career before open source was a thing.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00

speakers.text: I've long been critical of the way that open source is practiced. And one of the first contributions I made since my social justice awakening, if you will, was the creation of Contributor Covenant, which was unique at the time.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: of open source and how that fails, especially marginalized folks.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: But there's a specific incident in 2019 that started this particular effort. There's a Latinx,

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00
speakers.text: This particular effort, there's a Latinx, Chicanx activist organization called Mejente.

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_00

speakers.speaker: SPEAKER_01
speakers.text: It's such an incredible, incredible story.
